metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of Heihe remote sensing station, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Heihe remote sensing station from January 1 to December 31, 2021. The site (100.4756° E, 38.8270° N) was located on artificial grassland in Dangzhai Town of Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1560 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (1.5 m, north), wind speed and direction (10 m, north), air pressure (2 m), rain gauge (0.7 m), four-component radiometer (1.5 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (1.5 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), and two photosynthetically active radiation (1.5 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1.5, RH_1.5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, Ms_160 cm) (℃),on the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)). Due to the power loss, data during August 20 to October 9 were missing. Due to the sensor malfunction, the air temperature and relative humidity data were missing during January 1 to 22.
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2021-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of data collection methods for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a data collection method used to measure turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and gases such as carbon dioxide and methane in oasis–desert ecosystems. It involves high-frequency measurements of wind speed and gas concentration to calculate vertical fluxes, providing half-hourly data on ecosystem exchanges.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'scintillometer' in the context of measuring fluxes in oasis–desert areas?
Definition.Answer: A scintillometer is an instrument used in the context of measuring fluxes in oasis–desert areas to observe the turbulent fluxes over longer distances by measuring the refractive index of air. It complements eddy covariance systems in providing data on heat and mass transfer in the atmosphere.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques for meteorological elements in oasis–desert areas compare to those used in the artificial grassland settings of the Heihe River Basin?
Comparison.Answer: Both settings utilize automatic weather stations for data collection, with observations made at regular intervals (e.g., 10 minutes in Heihe River Basin and half-hourly in oasis–desert areas). The Heihe River Basin focuses specifically on meteorological elements like air temperature, humidity, and soil parameters, whereas oasis–desert areas additionally measure energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in challenges faced by inland river basins and oasis–desert systems in terms of ecological environment degradation?
Comparison.Answer: Both inland river basins and oasis–desert systems face challenges such as drying rivers, land desertification, and vegetation degradation. However, inland river basins like the Tarim River basin and others along the Silk Road specifically face issues such as the drying up of lakes and frequent dust storms, which may not be as emphasized in oasis–desert systems.

Comparison.Question: How does the approach to handling data quality control in the Heihe River Basin compare to that in oasis–desert observation datasets?
Comparison.Answer: In the Heihe River Basin, data quality control involves marking missing data with specific codes, removing duplicate records, and ensuring consistent formatting of date and time. Oasis–desert datasets also emphasize data processing and quality control through data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing, involving detailed checks for various hydrometeorological and flux-related observations.

Interpretation.Question: What methods could be employed to ensure continuous data collection in remote meteorological stations despite power supply issues?
Interpretation.Answer: The dataset notes a gap in data collection due to power supply issues from August 20 to October 9. Ensuring continuous data collection could involve using alternative power sources such as solar panels, backup generators, or energy storage systems to maintain the operation of the automatic weather stations.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of different data collection methods enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The metadata indicates the use of various sensors for observing meteorological and soil parameters. By integrating methods such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations, researchers can obtain a comprehensive dataset that captures multiple aspects of the ecosystem, thus providing a more holistic understanding of the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert areas.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in maintaining the accuracy and reliability of data collected from semi-arid regions, and how might they be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include data gaps due to environmental conditions, sensor malfunctions, and physical limitations of instruments. Addressing these could involve regular maintenance and calibration of sensors, implementing data validation and correction techniques, and using redundant systems to cross-verify data for accuracy and reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on data accuracy when implementing a 10-minute average period for hydrometeorological data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The adoption of a 10-minute average period for hydrometeorological data collection may lead to the efficient capture of short-term variations in environmental conditions, providing a detailed temporal resolution that helps in understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems. However, it might also introduce challenges in detecting rapid transient phenomena or outliers unless effectively managed by data processing and quality control procedures.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers impact the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for the precise acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, which is critical for a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems. This methodology contributes significantly to recognizing oasis-desert interactions and supports the goals of sustainable development by ensuring accurate and comprehensive data collection.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Missing data due to power supply and sensor issues can create gaps in the dataset, which may limit the ability to conduct continuous and reliable long-term monitoring of oasis-desert ecosystems. This can affect the analysis of trends and the understanding of ecosystem dynamics, potentially hindering efforts to maintain ecological stability and achieve sustainable development goals. Effective data processing and quality control measures are necessary to mitigate these gaps and ensure data integrity.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the quality and accuracy of data collected from automatic weather stations in arid and semiarid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures include ensuring that there are 144 data entries per day, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceed physical or instrument limits, marking questionable data with red, and standardizing date and time formats.

This is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting the socioeconomic development of oases.

These challenges can impact data accuracy and consistency in environmental datasets.

Expectation.Answer: Integrating hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters is necessary because these comprehensive datasets support the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert systems, which are essential for sustainable development and ecological security in arid regions.

Judgmental.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures involve several steps such as ensuring a set number of data entries per day, marking missing data with specific indicators, removing duplicates, and deleting data that surpasses physical or instrumental limits. These steps collectively contribute to maintaining data integrity, but challenges may still arise due to equipment malfunctions or environmental factors, as indicated by the noted data gaps due to power supply and sensor issues.

Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenges in maintaining long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid ecosystems include the degradation of ecological environments such as drying rivers and lakes, increased desertification, and frequent dust storms. These environmental challenges, alongside technical issues like power supply failures and sensor problems, complicate the consistent collection and quality of long-term datasets.
